docs.text: Open World Learning Introductory science education should feel as exhilerating as booting up a long-awaited open world RPG for the first time; a vast and wondrous world filled with mysteries to unravel and riddles to solve! The Open World Learning framework is a project where we explore and build collaborative online learning experiences within the Jupyter ecosystem, mainly focused on the physical sciences. Key ingredients: Python modules embedded on the framework Key ingredients to this framework are student-driven content generation, non-linear and graph based learning paths, personalized and AI-driven assessment, and embedded code and simulations designed to engage the students in computational thinking. The project is currently in its early stage of development with the support from Centre for Computing in Science Education and the The Hylleraas Centre for Quantum Molecular Sciences at the University of Oslo. Python modules embedded on the framework

docs.text: Open World Learning is maintaned by a small team of developers at the University of Oslo. .card { box-shadow: 0 4px 8px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2); max-width: 200px; margin: 5px 5px 5px 5px; padding: 25px; text-align: center; float: left; } .float-container { border: 3px solid #fff; padding: 20px; } .title { color: grey; font-size: 18px; } button { border: none; outline: 0; display: inline-block; padding: 8px; color: white; background-color: #000; text-align: center; cursor: pointer; width: 100%; font-size: 18px; } a { text-decoration: none; font-size: 22px; color: black; } button:hover, a:hover { opacity: 0.7; } Hanan Gharayba Chemistry (bachelor) Elias A. Dalan Chemistry (bachelor) Audun Skau Hansen The Hylleraas Centre for Quantum Molecular Sciences
